items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from this afternoon, Saturday 08/01/22. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Predicted peaks:- Llanymynech 3.0 to 3.5m Saturday afternoon, 08/01/22; Cae Howel 3.9 to 4.3m Sunday morning, 09/01/22.   
Further showers are forecast over the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 5pm on 08/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. Please note there is potential for levels to rise again tomorrow afternoon, Sunday 9th January. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding to low lying land and roads is possible from Saturday morning.

Heavy rain over the last 24 hours has caused river levels in the River Clyst and Culm catchments to rise. Further showers are forecast throughout the weekend which will cause levels to remain higher than normal. The highest levels are currently forecast for 9pm on Saturday.

We expect flooding to affect  Cullompton, Willand, Culmstock, Hemyock, Bradninch, Broadclyst, Clyst St Mary. Please take care near the areas of concern.
Do not walk or drive through flood water. Avoid low lying roads and footpaths, which may be flooded. 
 
Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation . 
  
This message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Tamar, River Strat, River Neet, River Ottery, River Kensey

items.message:
Flooding is possible from 2pm on Saturday 8th January. Heavy rain has been falling on saturated ground throughout the morning and river levels are rising. This may result in flooding to low lying land and roads close to rivers later this afternoon, particularly in the Tamarstone Bridge and Crowford Bridge areas. However, flooding to properties is not currently expected.  

We expect rivers to peak during the afternoon today and remain high throughout the remainder of Saturday and into Sunday morning. Further heavy showers are forecast for the rest of the weekend. 

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on Sunday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

items.message:
Flooding to low lying land and roads is possible from Saturday morning.

We expect flooding to affect  Lynton and Lynmouth, Challacombe, Meethe, South Molton, Dulverton, Brushford, Winsford, Exton, Exford. Please take care near the areas of concern.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding to low lying land and roads is possible from Saturday afternoon. 

Heavy rain has been falling across the River Exe catchment over the last 24 hours. This is causing river levels to rise.

We expect flooding to affect  Bickleigh, Up Exe, Rewe, Stoke Canon and Exeter. 
Do not walk or drive through flood water. Avoid low lying roads and footpaths, which may be flooded.

River levels will remain high throughout the weekend as further heavy showers are forecast, please take care near the areas of concern.

Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation . 
  
This message will be updated as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message: River levels at the Beggearn Huish river gauge are decreasing but remain above the Flood Alert threshold. The ground is saturated and will likely react to further rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible this evening, 08/01/22. We expect flooding to affect the Horner Water, Rivers Aller and Washford, and the Hawkcombe, Monksilver and Doniford Streams and tributaries. Further showery rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to continue to decrease, however they are likely to remain above the Flood Alert threshold throughout today, 08/01/22. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens and closing flood gates. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 11:00 on Sunday, 09/01/22, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.      
We continue to monitor the situation.  
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels are stable on the Bristol Avon at Bradford-on-Avon and on the Semington Brook at Semington.  Levels are expected to rise today due to this morning's rain but no Flood Warnings are currently forecast for this area.
Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.
Rain will ease through Saturday and only small amounts are forecast going in to next week.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated this afternoon.

River levels on Earby Beck have risen as a result of recent, heavy, rainfall. Consequently, flooding of low-lying roads and farmland is possible in daylight hours today, 08/01/22.  Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads near Earby Beck.

We expect river levels to remain high until around 17:00 this evening, 08/01/2022. The heaviest rainfall has passed but there may be some remaining risk of surface water impacts or standing water in the area. The rain is expected to clear later, and river levels should be able to drop throughout the rest of the weekend.

Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast.
  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  

This message will be updated by 21:00 on 08/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Duddon, River Crake, Mill Beck

items.message:
River levels have risen rapidly as a result of recent persistent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property is possible between 12pm and 3pm today.  Areas most at risk are properties closest to the watercourse. 
Further rainfall is forecast into this afternoon but will pass later today.  We expect river levels to peak around 1pm and remain elevated throughout the afternoon on 08/01/22.
We have sounded the Walsden Siren. We are closely monitoring the situation but we are not expecting any further river rises this weekend.   
  
This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

Please note there is potential for levels to rise again tomorrow afternoon, Sunday 9th January. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely. Water levels are continuing to remain high following recent tide locking. This combined with rainfall is likely to increase levels further. Levels are likely to remain high through today Saturday 8th January and into tomorrow. Water levels are expected to continue to rise gradually over the next few hours. This is due to a natural tide locking effect combined with today's rainfall. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry road in Horning. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Sunday 9th January.

High water levels with sea spray are forecast as a result of high tides and increased wind speeds. First forecast high water is 23:00 on 8/1/22 with a level of 4.21 mAOD and a Force 7 North Westerly wind. Second forecast high water is 11:30 on 9/1/22 with a level of 4.27 mAOD and a Force 6 Westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley Point, mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two hours either side of the high tide. We expect flooding to affect the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. Coastal conditions should ease for the 9/1/22 high tide at 23:45. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads. This message will be updated by 12:00 tomorrow on Sunday, 9/1/22, or as the situation changes.

items.message: The risk of flooding in the North Devon area has now reduced, and river levels are falling below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.
